children: is the primary agent of infectious mononucleosis and is associated with the development of B-cell lymphoma, T-cell lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Another EBV manifestation is oral hairy leukoplakia that characteristically affects the lateral portions of the tongue as white corrugated painless plaques.
Oral hairy leukoplakia is most commonly associated with underlying HIV infection.
Typical symptoms in patients with acute infectious mononucleosis include:
severe fatigue, headache, and sore throat
fever associated with posterior cervical lymphadenopathy
Consider EBV infection in all patients with aseptic meningitis or encephalitis, hepatitis, hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

The morbilliform rash appearing in patients with infectious mononucleosis following the administration of ampicillin is not an allergic reaction; patients can subsequently use ampicillin without rash recurrence.

Select a Monospot test (heterophile antibody test), which is specific but not very sensitive early in disease. If the Monospot test is negative, repeat in 2 weeks or select EBV serology. Infectious mononucleosis syndrome may also be caused by
or HIV infection; it is often not possible to make a clinical diagnosis, and serologic testing is necessary.
Select glucocorticoids only if airway obstruction or another life-threatening condition, such as hemolytic anemia, is present.
Do not prescribe antiviral drugs for treatment of infectious mononucleosis.

An 18-year-old female soccer player has malaise, anorexia, and a sore throat for 3 days. She has exudative pharyngitis, tender anterior and posterior cervical lymph nodes, and fullness in her left upper abdominal quadrant. Leukocyte count is 8500/Î¼L with moderate atypical lymphocytes.
For diagnosis, choose infectious mononucleosis. For management, select contact sport avoidance because of the risk of splenic rupture in the setting of splenomegaly.
